awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2023 International Symposium on Computer Architecture (ISCA)
awd_abstract_narration:
The International Symposium on Computer Architecture (ISCA), renowned as the premier forum for cutting-edge advancements in computer architecture, offers an exceptional platform for exchange of state-of-the art research. This award provides travel support for up to 75 students attending this flagship conference on June 17-21, 2023, in Orlando, FL. Over the past five decades, ISCA has played a pivotal role in fostering remarkable progress within the computing industry. Distinguished attendees, representing both academia and industry from all over the world, contribute to the conference’s diverse and vibrant atmosphere. Within a wide array of sessions, the conference encompasses the latest developments across many categories, including core microarchitecture topics, machine learning, security, and much more. The keynotes delve into the historical technological advancements of the past 50 years as chronicled through ISCA publications. Through engaging social events, students have the invaluable opportunity to interact with esteemed leaders in computing, both seasoned professionals and rising stars. In 2023, ISCA proudly commemorates its 50th anniversary, coinciding with the Federated Computing Research Conference (FCRC), a collection of high-quality conferences and workshops in the broader field of Computer Science, held once every four years.

The benefits of this award are threefold. Firstly, by promoting increased student participation, it amplifies the visibility of the groundbreaking research being presented while honoring the 50-year legacy of this premier conference. Secondly, undergraduate and junior graduate students gain access to exclusive programs such as “Meet a Senior Architect” and “Meet a Senior Student,” which foster meaningful communication and interactions with experienced professionals. These initiatives enhance the conference experience by providing valuable mentorship opportunities. Lastly, the travel award places a particular emphasis on supporting students from traditionally underrepresented groups, aligning with ISCA’s commitment to diversity and inclusion. By addressing financial barriers, the award strives to create a more inclusive environment that reflects the broad spectrum of talent in the field of computer Architecture.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
The International Symposium on Computer Architecture (ISCA) is the premier forum state-of-art work in computer architecture, and in 2023 was part of the Federated Computing Research Conference (FCRC), a collection of top tier computing conferences that are organized in the same location every four years. The travel award grant provided the organizing committee the financial support to allow a total of 56 students to attend this historic event that too place on June 17-21 2023 in Orlando, FL. In 2023, ISCA also celebrated its 50th anniversary.

The benefits of this award were threefold. First, it allowed the organizing committee to promote an increase in student participation, by supporting a total of 56 students, 34 whom were first time attendees. The award helped these students cover their travel expenses. By attending the conference, the students were able to meet senior computer architects as well as top researchers from the programming langugages and operating systems communities (based on the student's responses regarding their conference experiences) thanks to the FCRC conglomerate. In addition, attending the conference helped many students increase the visibility of their own work, some of which was presented at the conference . In addition, all students participated in the Meet a Senior Architect and Meet a Senior Student programs, which organizes individual meetups with senior researchers. These interactions foster more meaningful interactions and helps new members of the community find new networking avenues. Finally, 41% of the students supported were part of  under-represented groups, which helped in increasing the diversity of the conference participants. 

The award helped cover up to $500 in expenses such as airplane, hotel and transportation costs for a total of 56 students. 61% of the students were first time attendees and 41% were from under-represented groups. 87% of students were PhD students, 4% were master students and 9% were undergraduate students.  There were a total of 22 univesities represented. 


Last Modified: 07/26/2024
Modified by: Tamara S Lehman
